passage_text: The hectare (/ˈhɛktɛər/ or /ˈhɛktɑr/ ; symbol ha) is an SI accepted metric system unit of area equal to 100 ares (10,000 m 2) and primarily used in the measurement of land. An acre is about 0.4047 hectare and one hectare contains about 2.47 acres.

Most sports fields are one hectare in size. The Apple Bowl in Kelowna for instance is a 400 m running track and the grassy area inside is 1.12 hectares. The international rugby field pictured above is very close to one hectare in size, it is actually 1.0008 hectares. A perfect square is 100 meters by 100 meters is a hectare. To find out how many acres in hectares, multiply by the conversion factor or simply use the converter below. 1 Hectare = 2.47105381 Acres. Hectare is a metric system area unit and widely used globally for land measurement, agriculture and forestry. It equals to 10,000 square meters. The abbreviation is ha.

Used widely in the US customary system and the Imperial system, an acre is a unit of area equal to 1/640 of a square mile, or 0.4047 of a hectare, or 43,560 square feet. To imagine what an acre is, one can imagine the area which is equal to approximately 3/4 of the common football field.

Its use is widespread in agriculture where it is more practical than either square metres or square kilometres, typical fields being a few hectares in size. An acre is a measure of land area in Imperial units or U.S. customary units. It is equal to 43 560 square feet, 4840 square yards, or 160 square rods.
